A firefighter was killed after being run over by his own car in a freak accident. 
Tommy Macaulay, 55, was crushed to death when his vehicle rolled on top of him outside a house in Scotland. 
Today, his daughter Lauren paid an emotional tribute to the "most hard-working, selfless man you could ever meet". 
The cause of Friday’s accident in the Highland village of Helmsdale is unclear, but police said there are no suspicious circumstances. 
The community was described as “a sad village united in grief” yesterday for one the its best-loved characters, the Daily Record reported . The hard-working firefighter was a member of the Tartan Army of Scottish football lovers (Photo: Daily Record) Read More Housekeeper killed after tree police failed to seal off fell on top of her in storm 
Tartan Army veteran Tommy was described by daughter Lauren, 22, as “the Helmie footsoldier” . 
She set up the Tommy Macaulay Book of Condolences on Facebook, which was quickly flooded with tributes and stories about her dad’s travels and exploits. 
Lauren said: “He was the most hard-working, selfless man you could ever meet. 
"He would help out anyone even without being asked. He has been to so many Scotland games and travelled all over to support the Scotland team. 
“He has met so many of the Scotland players and told Gordon Strachan a few tactics when he seen him too. Mr Macaulay was described by his daughter as the "most selfless man" (Photo: Daily Record) Read More Speeding teen's car flies through air and smashes into taxi after he fled police with no licence 
“My dad took me all over the world. I have been to many a Scotland game. He taught me all the songs and we sang them together with pride. 
“My dad was also a fantastic firefighter. He made me proud every time he was out at a call. 
"If you heard his pager, dad would be running out the door leaving whatever he was doing unfinished. 
“My dad always put everyone else first and would do what needed to be done to keep them safe. 
"He taught me how to look after myself and how to deal with any situations that arose.” 
Lauren shared memories of her dad playing for Helmsdale United FC, starring at darts and as a member of the Bunillidh rowing team. 
Many local events were postponed as a mark of respect. Lauren added: “I’ll always be daddy’s little girl and I’ll always look out for my mum. 
“We will spend a long time mourning his loss but, as a family and community, I know that together we will get through this horrendous tragedy. The tragedy unfolded in the Scottish Highland village of Helmsdale Read More Road rage spat between cyclist and driver sparks vicious argument as rider shouts 'you f***ing nearly hit me off!' 
“Tommy Macaulay – the best man I know. I love you daddy, you will always be in my heart and I will cherish all the memories we made together. 
“I love you so so so much words can’t even explain. It hurts so much that your not here and that I can’t tell you just how much you mean to me.” 
Tommy, who is also survived by widow Jane and her son Shaun, was honoured with a minute’s silence at North Caley League games at the weekend. 
A police spokesman said: “Emergency services were called to a property in the Navidale area near Helmsdale at around 4pm on Friday following the sudden death of a 55-year-old man. 
“There are no suspicious circumstances and a report will be submitted to the procurator fiscal.” Like us on Facebook
